Name: Bag of Dungeon: Legends Expansion Print & Play
Description:
Legends is a print-and-play expansion for Bag of Dungeon. It adds a new Wizard Character Card (with spells), Skill tokens which can be used for instant power-ups or as permanent skills (upgrades), and Hidden-agenda Cards which allow players to win additional kills (victory points) at the end of the game.

—description from the publisher

Name: Fire Brigade
Description:
The game was developed in cooperation with professional firefighters and it includes realistic situations and educational content.

Fire Brigade is a cooperative game. Players are members of the fire brigade. Their goal is to save citizens by rescuing and transporting them from endangered areas to the hospital. At the same time, they want to prevent buildings from burning down and keep the fire contained by preventing the spread of a raging inferno. This game can be played in two modes. In Normal Mode players try to save as many citizens as they can, while in Expert Mode they must save all of the citizens or they lose the game.

The board consists of hexes with different areas (grass, forest, wetlands etc.) with drier areas having more chances to catch on fire. Buildings, Citizens and Fire Tokens are placed on the board according to the chosen scenario. There are nine scenarios for different number of players and difficulties.

Each player gets a Squad Card along with the matching Fire Truck Miniature and Starting Hex and is assigned one random Firefighting Ability Card and one random Utility Ability Card. That gives each Squad unique abilities to achieve the given goals easier.

The game has multiple rounds, each following the same procedure. Each round is divided into three phases: Fire-spreading Phase, Event Phase and Players’ Actions Phase.

In the Fire-spreading Phase the first player rolls the two Fire Dice. The sum of both numbers determines which hexes will be additionally affected by fire this turn. The fire intensifies and spreads according to the dice roll. If the fire intensifies too much, the Fire Tokens are replaced with an Inferno Token. Buildings on those hexes have burned to the ground and the Citizens are lost.

Then comes the Event Phase which changes the situation on the board. Events can be positive, negative or both.  There is an interesting fact about firemen and fire at the bottom of each event card.

The last phase is the Players’ Actions Phase. When it is their turn, each player can perform any combination of three basic actions (i.e. has three action points) and any number of free actions. The basic actions are: move Fire truck, extinguish fire, use Firefighting ability, use Utility ability, repair the Fire Truck, and evacuate Citizens. The free actions are: drop off Citizens in the Hospital and get Motivation Card, use Motivation card, drop off Citizens temporarily and pick them up after being dropped off. Players can pass at any point of their turn.

At the End of the game, players can check how well they did. Points are awarded based on how well the fire was contained and how many buildings were burned down. The score is then compared to the Score table which places players in categories from one to five stars, with stars being lost for every lost Citizen. By calculating their score, the players see how well they did and take a scenario with higher or lower difficulty, or try to beat their score in the same scenario next time.

—description from the publisher

Name: Necromancy: The Exhumation
Description:
You are and evil Necromancer, searching the mouldering crypts and dusty tombs for decomposed cadavers, unholy spirits and demonic fiends to arise and do your infernal bidding. But you're not alone in this dark and forgotten place; a rival of equal evil awaits...

Necromancy: the Exhumation is a micro-card-game reminiscent of Magic: the Gathering but simpler in scale and scope.

The game is played by 2-players using a shared 20-card draw deck. Each card serves one of two purposes: as a creature or as a spell. On each turn players draw a card and take up to two separate actions: drawing or playing cards as creatures or spells. Each card has different attributes and effects and these are used to "attack" the other player and reduce their health points to zero.

Name: Purrballs: Catventure Card Game – Secret Store Expansion Pack
Description:
"Many rumors exist among the chatty Catventurers, but none are as persistent as that of a mysterious store. Some say it moves from place to place, sometimes within the blink of an eye. Others whisper about the cloaked figure seated behind the counter. But all agree on its goods, powerful and valuable beyond compare, with a price tag to match..."

The Secret Store is the first expansion pack for the Purrballs: Catventure Card Game. It introduces Coins, a valuable resource that counts as XP (experience points) at the end of the game. Gain Coins by cashing in Bounties, trading in your valuable Loot cards for a fat purseful. Gather enough, and you can then purrchase Store cards; their powerful abilities are sure to help when you most need it!

—description from the publisher

Name: Shadowrift: Promo Pack 1
Description: This promo pack adds three new villager cards to your Shadowrift Game. The Guide, the bartender, and the Kidnapper.

Name: Cricaré: The Indian Holocaust – Wargame in Brazilian Colonial Era
Description:
The Battle of Cricaré was one of the bloodiest massacres carried out by the Portuguese against Tupinambá - Tupinikín Indians. It happened on the São Mateus River, also known as Cricaré, in the until then Povoado do Cricaré, including on the Mariricu River (variation of the word Marerike, which means fortress of pau-a-pique), in the current state of Espírito Santo, at the beginning of the year 1558.

Fernão de Sá, son of Mem de Sá governor-general of Brazil at the time, when he arrived in Porto Seguro in Bahia, he received the information that there were many Indians in the region of the village of Cricaré. He set up a punitive expedition with about six caravels and 200 men. He disembarked on the banks of the Cricaré and began to slaughter the Gentiles, using their firearms against the ill-armed Indians.

By underestimating the bravery of the Indians and the carelessness of the soldiers, the governor’s son went a long way in the persecution and ran out of powder. The Indians realized and advanced on him that he was only with ten men. He was killed along with Manuel Álvares and Diogo Álvares, both son of Diogo Álvares Correia, The Caramuru - The man of fire - and three other soldiers.

Despite this victory by the Indians, a large number of Portuguese soldiers joined the Cricaré River region, killing thousands of Indians. However, two notable facts occurred: the first defeat of the Portuguese on the Brazilian coast and, in return, the greatest genocide committed against the Indians in Brazil.

The Bellum Brasilis series was originally produced by the extinct Riachuelo Games and was directed to games at the tactical level, covering several episodes in the history of Brazil. 
This wargame is the second in the Voxelhouse Old School Wargames series.

—description from the publisher

Name: Cuba & Filipinas: Spanish-American War
Description:
The Spanish-American War of 1898 was decided at sea, where both navies, with their shortcomings and strengths, gave their best.

Cuba & Filipinas is the expansion of Mar Rojo that covers this forgotten conflict. To play Cuba & Filipinas a copy of Mar Rojo is essential.

What does the Cuba & Filipinas expansion include:


     A deck of 50 new fleet cards, including all the important ships of the conflict, and others, that in different circumstances could have participated (such as the battleship Pelayo or the armored cruiser Maine).



     Two new action cards: RAM and DYNAMITE.



     A four-page mini rulebook with two new scenarios and the possibility of DYO (design your own) scenarios.

Name: REACTOR
Description:
Join the global community and manage your resources as you build your nation’s Economy, Global Engagement, Military, Human Progress, and Satisfaction. Can you lead your country to an age of happiness and prosperity?

REACTOR is a light, quick playing civilization building strategy game commissioned by NSquare and designed for use in the classroom to create teachable moments highlighting the dangers of nuclear weapons.

Gameplay
Each turn consists of 3 phases in this order: Infrastructure, Action, and Aftermath

Infrastructure Phase
Starting with the first player, everyone chooses one category to raise up 2 levels.

Action Phase
Each player secretly chooses which action they will take by playing the corresponding card face down in front of themselves. There are 5 possible actions. Economic Progress: Add resources to any category. Global Responsibility: Create an alliance and/or generate resources. Human Achievement: Add resources to your lowest category. Satisfaction: Convert military resources to any other category and get bonus resources. Military: Invade or Nuke another nation. All actions are explained in greater detail below.

Once all players have locked in a choice, the cards are revealed, and the actions are resolved starting with the first player.

Aftermath Phase
Players with an active alliance automatically produce additional resources which can be placed anywhere. Allied players receive 1 resource per alliance at level 2, 2 resources per alliance at level 5, and 3 resources per alliance at level 10.

Then the first player marker is moved clockwise from the current first player and a new round begins.

End

At the end of the game, any nations with a total score of 30 or more points from all categories, except Military, (or with a Satisfaction level of 8+ and total score of 25 or more points) are considered winners unless all remaining nations have winning totals in which case the player with the lowest Satisfaction score loses. If players have a tie for lowest Satisfaction score then break that tie with their point total from the other three categories.

If all nations have been Nuked, then everyone loses.

If only 1 Nation remains, that nation is technically “the winner” but they are now the sole survivors of a nuclear wasteland.

Among younger demographics, the nuclear issue is abstract and distant—a problem of previous generations. There are more resonant issues like social injustice, global warming, or economy disparity that, while still daunting, are far more comprehensible and consequential.
Reactor, engages high school students in the classroom about the nuclear weapons threat by connecting this issue to more visible social matters through an interactive and accessible medium. By breaking down the complexity of this problem with play, students cultivate a sense of understanding that drives engagement, helping foster new generations that feel empowered and responsible to take action.

About NSquare: 
In 2014, five of the largest peace and security funders in the United States joined forces to develop a new, collective approach to incentivizing and rewarding innovation in the nuclear threat field. What emerged was N Square, a path-breaking initiative built on the idea that new forms of cross-sector collaboration—combined with the sheer ingenuity of an engaged public­—will accelerate the achievement of internationally agreed goals to reduce nuclear dangers.

—description from the designer

Name: Connect with Pieces: Star Trek Into Darkness
Description:
Show your friends who’s the ultimate puzzler in the new Star Trek Connect With Pieces Puzzle Building Game! Each puzzle piece has one of 5 symbols on it (they are cleverly pressed in so that they are only visible when looking for them). Score points by finding the right pieces! Match up more symbols for more points! Featuring 2 modes of play, you can ramp up the speed or the strategy for different play styles. Featuring a proprietary manufacturing method. The primary image is maintained while the game play is layered in for a unique take on this classic activity.

Features & details

     Great Collectable.
     Official Licensed Product.
     Each puzzle piece has a symbol embossed into the piece-match symbols to score points.
     Clever design of the puzzle allows for some pieces to be placed in multiple locations.
     700 piece puzzle game.


—description from the publisher

Name: Tokyo Washi Game Cops
Description:
Take on the role of a Japanese police officer as you find evidence and solve crimes! You can eat ramen to boost your energy and execute special moves, and when you find the criminal, draw their face!

This game takes place on a roll of Washi tape, and is thus endlessly modular and scales up to any player count.

—description from the publisher

Name: Woody Woodpecker wird gejagt
Description:
One player (Woody Woodpecker) starts at the red center space. The other players start at the corners of their color. Movement is determined by a die. Woody Woodpecker may move in any direction, the hunters may only move forward. They are only allowed to use the blue dots if they are on a rectangular blue space and roll a 1 or a 6. If a hunter player catches Woody Woodpecker, he gets a chip and  changes the roles with the Woody Woodpecker player. Woody Woodpecker continues to play, while the hunters have to roll a 6 to continue their hunt.
The player who has the most chips after an agreed on amount of time wins the game.

—user summary

Name: PizzaGross
Description:
In PizzaGross you are running a shabby pizza shop, trying to convince your customers that your product is edible enough to justify paying for it. Try to save as much money as possible on ingredients, while keeping the customers happy with their purchases.

PizzaGross is a card drafting game with an economic component. Players must collect sets of ingredient cards to create pizzas of varying qualities. After drafting the ingredient cards, players choose which of them they shall buy. The cheapest ingredients are obtained for no money at all, but higher quality cards require some investment. When selling pizzas, players will face customers of different levels of rigorousness. Rotten ingredients may satisfy some customers, but others will notify the authorities, who will close the business for the day.

After three rounds, the player with the most money is the winner.

-description from designer

Name: The Drums (fan expansion for T.I.M.E Stories)
Description:
This fan-made scenario for T.I.M.E Stories is a single player expansion. It tells a tale of atmospheric horror in the woods of Kentucky. It is set in 1974.

—description from the designer

Name: SkirmishCampaigns: Red Guards at Kursk
Description:
SkirmishCampaigns:Russia 43- Red Guards at Kurskis a complete book for recreating skirmish-level battles and campaigns centered on the Soviet 11th Guards Army and its thrust on the northern flank of the Kursk salient in July 1943. This is the second in a set of two books (the first is Gross Deutschland at Kursk) focused on the titanic struggle around Kursk.
Maximum Replayability: the SkirmishCampaigns system features a realistic variable order of battle for each scenario, guaranteeing countless unique scenario and campaign replays.

Generic Order of Battle: this book also includes a unique generic order of battle listing that can be translated to almost any skirmish rule system.

Historical Research: this book includes several introduction sections that contain background information on the German offensive at Kursk in 1943.

Includes:

     10 Scenarios,
     3 Campaigns


Compatible with these and other Skirmish Rules: Battleground, Beer and Pretzels Skirmish (BAPS), ARC of FIRE, Face of Battle, Men of Frost, Overlord, Battalions in Crisis, Battlefront WWII, Cross of Iron, And in the Beginning, Skirmish '90, and more.

—description from the publisher

Name: Neocity 2081
Description:
This game was attached to the ioGioco 7 magazine.

The evil boss Karl Blueyes organizes illegal futuristic motorcycle races every Saturday night, thus fueling his profitable round of illegal business. In the improvised arena that uses city streets, the champions of the two most feared urban gangs, the Wheels of Judgment and the Gods of Atomic Speed, face off. During the race, the two drivers try to put the opposing motorcycle at gunpoint using the light tracer. Who at the end of the race will have scored more tracers on the other bike will be the winner!

To move his motorcycle, the player plays one of his numbered cards. At the end of the turn, a tracer can also play in the space provided. If a player plays a card to move, the value of which is equal to that of a tracer already played, this tracer is activated and the motorcycle behind (to understand who it is, you need to determine the shorter arc that separates the two motorcycles) can shoot, taking by the tracer card. On the tracer cards there are the symbols of the hits, whoever has collected the most hits at the end of the race wins.

—user summary

Name: Dirty Highlights
Description:
This game was attached to the ioGioco 8 magazine.

The race has just ended but some fraudulent directors are not interested in telling the truth. Everyone is in the pay of a different team and tries, with still images, forward and rewind, to mount a summary of the race that gives greater visibility to the team for which he works in secret.

The game board represents the last section of the circuit, and is divided into squares. The cars are three-dimensional and are moved in turn by each player following precise rules (the machines move one or two squares only orthogonally and pushing each other), five times before determining the end of the lap. Thanks to special cards ("Freeze", "Skip" and "Prev & Play") it is possible to influence the sequence of movements.

—user summary

Name: Ferro, Fango e Neve: L'operazione Barbarossa in 50 minuti
Description:
Ferro, Fango e Neve is a World War II wargame that was attached to issue 9 of the ioGioco Italian game magazine.

On June 22, 1941 Hitler unleashes Operation Barbarossa and surprisingly invades the Soviet Union. It is a struggle against time: the Germans must bring the USSR to its knees before Stalin regroups and goes to the counterattack.

—user summary
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Bacchematica
Description:
This game was attached to issue 11 of the ioGioco magazine.

The forest is full of juicy berries and fragrant fruits. Each animal, sniffing the air, listening to the rustle of the leaves and calculating the best routes, tries to reach the richest bushes. But other gluttons target the same succulent fruits. We must hurry, before someone faster blows us under the nose, or better to say under the muzzle, our favorite acorns or the red strawberries.

Each turn you draw a bush tile characterized by a value (its position in the woods) and two mathematical operations. Then you turn a "track" piece, which indicates numerical values corresponding to colored positions. The player tries to use the numerical values together with the operations, putting them in the right order on his board to reach a number as close as possible to that of the bush.

—user summary

Name: Darkball
Description:
Darkball is a first of its kind game in which players put their timing to the test against a speedy disappearing ball and each other. Darkball rewards accuracy, reaction times, as well as creativity. As the pieces are rearranged, the ball can travel in any direction, and down any path with no limits to the number of players or ways it can be played.

Any endpoint Blink displaying cyan has a Darkball. Play begins when one player presses their endpoint Blink to release the Darkball. The ball moves along the pathway, making decisions randomly when it reaches forks. Clustered pathways are treated as forks, and can produce very chaotic behavior.

When the Darkball reaches your endpoint, you must press the button to bounce it back into the pathway. If you click too early, your endpoint will go dark for a moment, and you cannot press again until it brightens. If you press too late, you will take damage, as indicated by red lights on your endpoint. You can then release the Darkball by pressing.

Once a player has missed the Darkball 6 times, their endpoint will explode, and they are out. The last player remaining is the winner.

Name: Mecha Brawl
Description:
This game was attached to issue 13 of the ioGioco magazine.

Year 2811: Earth is a dead planet and the world population has sought survival in colonies outside the world. After a series of bloody wars to dominate the solar system, fought with huge battle mechs, the colonies have lived in precarious peace for decades. The memory of the last Great War remains alive and is celebrated with a tournament that takes place annually on the surface of the devastated planet Earth: the Mecha Brawl.
Mercenaries, ex-soldiers and adventurers challenge each other on board their mechs for glory and money, led by generals hired by the Colonies. You are one of them, and you have been called to manage the team that will represent your colony in the next tournament: choose two teams of mercenaries, deploy your team and prepare for battle!

Name: Starfire Quick Start Rules
Description:
The Quick Start Rules are a highly simplified set of tactical combat rules for starship combat based on the Solar Starfire ruleset. Written in three sections, this 11-page rulebook contains the basic tactical rules, six scenarios, and the printable counters and map required for the scenarios. Th Quick Start Rules are designed for players new to the Starfire System and introduce all of the basic concepts of the Starfire tactical game.

—description from the designer

Name: The Fight: We gonna fight them all!
Description:
Welcome to The Fight!

You and your fellow crew have heard of an abandoned dungeon with rumors of great treasures inside, yet nobody else but you has dared to check the truth about these rumors — and now you know why: A horde of monsters inside the dungeon got bored and now they crave a good fight.

There is no time for a long strategy session. Use the weapons at hand, making the right combined decisions of how to fight against the various monsters without revealing too much information to them as blind trust in your crew may be the best chance you have to coordinate your strengths.

The Fight is played in fifty levels. Each level takes only a few minutes, with you fighting against a certain number of monsters. Typically, one monster lies face up in the center of play, and your crew needs to beat its strength value in one attack to win the fight. For each attack, you all place one card from your hand face down in front of you. If your revealed fighting total matches or exceeds the value of a face-up monster, you beat it; otherwise, the monster remains face up and keeps fighting.

To win a level, you can discuss your strategy with your crew. You can never talk about your card values in hand, but can debate whether you want to "strike fast" or "take it slow". You can also use available special actions to gain the most benefits from them.

—description from the publisher

Name: 7 Fortunes
Description:
7 Fortunes is a 2 - 6 Player Battle Arena Board Game, based upon the rich content and stories of Greek Mythology.

     Players pick from a pool of 35 Champions
     Participate in a “Stacking” Mini Card Game in which they gain Wealth and Hero Points.
     Use their Champion Abilities, Aquire & Collect Items, and Battle Other Players!
     All while Progressing to a Target Victory Point Count or the Elimination of all the other players for the win!


—description from the designer

Name: Arctic Race
Description:
Arctic Race is a competition across the ice.
Jump on to ice floes and choose your strategy, take short cuts through the arctic universe to be the first to cross the finish line. 
Move one of your five different race contestants, but take care not to be pushed out by your opponents, or you will have to start all over again.

In Arctic Race all players control five different racers each, competing in different races but on the same track affecting each other. Players simultaneously choose a card to move a racer or take a secondary action. Cards are revealed in turn and the start player token is of high value as the board can change a lot with racers and ice floes moving.

The game ends when one or more players have finished the race with three of their racers, or when there are no more ice floes to put in the river. 
The winner is the player with most points for finished races.

—description from the designer

Name: A Death in the Red Light
Description:
Amsterdam, 1988. The Red Light District is a hive of sex and drugs. You take the role of a Police Detective. A dead body has turned up on the streets. You must examine the clues, follow the leads and solve the puzzles in order to uncover the truth of what happened in this real historical case.

In a combination choose-your-adventure and puzzle game, there are multiple paths you can take to solving the mystery. Play alone or with friends. The game can be played online or printed out at home.

The Noir graphic style and jazz soundtrack work together to immerse you in the grimy police work of the Red Light District.

—description from the designer

Name: Glass Bead
Description:
Glass Bead is a territory game for two players: Red and Blue. It is played on the spaces of an initially empty square board. Recommended sizes are between 7x7 and 10x10 spaces.

An empty space is controlled by the player with more stones adjacent to it. Diagonal adjacencies also count. A space occupied by a stone is controlled by the owner of that stone.

Red plays first, then turns alternate. On your turn, place a stone of your color on a empty space that is not controlled by either player.

The game ends when no more placements are possible. The player who controls more spaces in the final position wins.

According to the designer, this game, later reworked into Kuzushi, suffers from a huge first-player advantage. It is suggested to use komi (compensation points for the second player) to solve this issue.

Name: Quatorze
Description:
The magic number "7" conjures up meanings, powers, and  coincidences dating back to the dawn of time. In Quatorze, you establish seven columns that utilize the powers of these powerful 7s. Players take turns adding cards to these columns, while trying to retain high-value cards in their hand. When the game ends, the highest combined value of cards in hand wins.

However, the powers of cards played to the columns during the game can drastically change the way cards are scored, and each player is trying to maneuver these powers to their advantage! Can you best harness and use these powerful 7s?

Quatorze is a sequel to Jason Tagmire's Seven7s and includes the original game within it as well. Thus, instead of seven suits, the game now includes fourteen!

—description from the publisher

Name: Guards and Martyrs: The Battle for Basra, December 1986-April 1987
Description:
"Guards and Martyrs: The Battle for Basra, December 1986-April 1987" is a two-player Operational level board-wargame of one of the largest and bloodiest battle of the whole Iran-Iraq War.

“The battle for Basra will be the mother of all battles.” –Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani to the Iranian Supreme Defense Council, January 23, 1987.

The Iran-Iraq War was starting its seventh year by the start of Winter in 1986. Casualties on both sides numbered in the hundreds of thousands and both sides had resorted to chemical weapons, missile attacks against their opponent’s cities, and an escalating air and sea campaign in the Persian Gulf that threatened to bring Super power intervention. The Iranian government felt that an offensive to take the crucial city of Basra, Iraq’s only port and primary gateway for shipping out its oil and receiving goods from abroad, could end the war with a victory. Dubbed “Karbala 5” the Iranians amassed much of their Revolutionary Guard formations supported by new weapons secretly purchased from the “Great Satan” USA (via the illegal Iran-Contra affair) as well as North Korea. A feint attack north of the battlefield, Karbala 6, by much of the Iranian armored force would tie up Iraq’s reserves. The resulting battle for Basra was one of the largest and bloodiest battles fought in the war, with both sides fighting with all they had. In the end the battle for Basra would prove just as indecisive as the larger war, with neither side able to claim a clear victory.

Can you do as well or better than your historical counterparts? Learn and enjoy!

—description from the publisher
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: To Rule the Waves: Naval Battles in the Mediterranean in the 1880s.
Description:
“The surer of himself an admiral is, the finer the tactical development of his fleet, the better his captains, the more reluctant must he necessarily be to enter into a melee with equal forces, in which all these advantages will be thrown away, chance reign supreme, and his fleet be place on terms of equality with an assemblage of ships which have never before acted together.”—Alfred Thayer Mahan, The Influence of Seapower Upon History, 1660-1783.

To Rule The Waves is an introductory level wargame simulation on the British Navy’s bombardment of the Egyptian Forts at Alexandria in 1882, as well as several “what if” naval battles that could have occurred amongst the European powers in the Mediterranean during the 1880s. This decade was marked by peace amongst the Imperialist nations, but there were events that “rocked the boat” and could very easily have led to conflict; especially in the Mediterranean Sea that for ages has been the nexus of commerce as well as conflict. This decade was also marked by tremendous innovation in warship design and tactics. The pace of change was such that no nation could rest assured that their fleet’s composition was proven or superior to that of their opponent. This was not an easy time for Admirals and ships’ captains…

The game design is meant to be simple and highly playable, yet one that portrays the historical challenges facing the combatants.

Learn and enjoy!

—description from the publisher

Name: Universal Rule: Singularity
Description:
The war rages on. Alliances are forming and breaking faster than you can decide which side to align with. The new themes of meanies (direct player to player aggression) will quickly help in your decision making. You can work on taking over the universe together, but in the end, only one can rule.

Universal Rule: Singularity is a standalone expansion to Universal Rule.

It can be played in one of the following ways:


     Play Singularity all by itself.
     Randomize 17 Planet cards and 1 Edge card.
     Choose your favorite combination of 17 Planet cards and 1 Edge card.


In Universal Rule: Singularity, players battle for control of the universe in this pocket-sized 4X style game. You can colonize new planets, explore new areas on those planets, gain credits based off of the resources that the planet produces, or attempt to destroy other planets that threaten your existence. Other players can follow, but at a cost. The first player to show their true dominance through victory points wins the game.


Edge:

     Deep Space Edge


Planets:

     Dothater
     Carnoxide
     Wamous
     Kryptotrix
     Starvex
     Icrillon
     Oor's Landing
     Bani Roma
     Cucarro
     Kellade
     Prerette
     Koxii
     Echorum
     Mado II
     Interzino
     Virania
     Adwauld



Released in the April 2020 Board Game of the Month Club $20+ package.
Families: Players: Games with expansions that add solo play

Name: Universal Rule: Solo AI #1
Description:
After a journey through deep space, your expedition greets a new galaxy full of promise and danger. The galaxy was thought to be uninhabited, but robotic explorers have just established a colony and are already surveying additional planets. All alone in this new frontier, will you be able to overcome the relentless advance of your mechanized opposition?

Universal Rule: Solo AI #1 is a solo expansion to Universal Rule.

It can be played in one of the following ways:

1. Play using one of the base games:

     Universal Rule
     Second Wave
     Singularity.


2. Randomize 17 Planet cards and 1 Edge card.
3. Choose your favorite combination of 17 Planet cards and 1 Edge card.


Planet:

     Cinda

Name: Fable on Your Table
Description:
Fable on Your Table is a print-and-play "roguelike" miniatures game where you take on the role of an adventurer and plunge into a dungeon trying to complete an objective.

Play out the battles with papercraft miniatures you cut out and assemble (or use your own!), guided by the companion web app that procedurally generates the dungeons you explore.  When you complete a quest, you level up.  Level up five times to ascend and win the game!

The miniatures rules may also be used for general tabletop miniatures play with scenarios you invent. The rules are generic enough that they can be used with your own miniatures and terrain, and there are even rules for playing grid-less.

To play the game in the manner intended you need to use the companion app/website, but you could also use Fable on your Table as a miniatures skirmish system for a TTRPG experience, and make up your own scenarios.  The app is there to enable solo play, but the system itself doesn't rely on the app to work, any more than any other TTRPG combat system does.  For instance, you could write up your own adventures and share them with friends, and it would work perfectly fine.

Name: Legends of Destiny
Description:
Legends of Destiny is a wild west board game for 1 to 4 players taking about 1.5 to 2 hours. You and your friends are competing to be the biggest legends of the town of Destiny.  Track your character's assets and abilities on role playing style character sheets. Each turn, players will move and draw one destiny card and play one card.  All interactions in the game are dictated by the play of your destiny cards.  Purchase better weapons, boots, a new hat or a horse.  Visit the doctor or buy some snake oil.  Gamble or buy whiskey at the local saloons.  Gunfights will occur and and law will issue wanted posters for gunmen. The player who completes six missions first is the winner.

—description from the publisher

Name: You are the ghost
Description:
A prentender game: One player is the pretender (in this game "ghost")and try to pass as a "normal" player:
Everyone except the pretender is hearing the same sound via a smart device and then picks a card and explains why this card fits to the sound. The pretender still as to pick a card and bluff. At the end everyone tries to find the pretender. 
Points are awarded for correctly guessing the pretender and for the pertender if he gets annoticed or, if he is caught, can guess which sound the other players have heard

Name: The Grumpy Nisse
Description:
Violet is a young girl who is nothing but trouble to her parents. Being adventurous and ignoring her parents' warnings about the dangers in the forest, she decides one night to climb out her bedroom window and wander into the forest, hoping to discover hidden treasures to be found only under the moonlight. What she doesn't know is that she is fated to become best friends (the greatest of treasures) with a kind Troll... if she bumps into him before the sun rises. For when the sunlight hits a troll, they transform into a rock for the day. And if this was to happen, Violet would never again have the chance to meet this particular troll.

The grumpy Nisse Torech though, will have no such thing! Aware of what fate has reserved for Violet, and opposing such nonsense as trolls befriending humans, he will do all in his power, to prevent Violet from meeting this troll.

The Grumpy Nisse, is a 2-player card game where one player is Violet and the other is Torech. Torech tries to prevent Violet from reaching the end of the forest before sunrise, in which case he will win the game. Players will play out one card each and compare their strengths to determine who wins the round, if Violet, then she will progress, otherwise she'll have to try again. Some of the spots in the forest will trigger events that can make the game harder for either one or the other player, so players need to be careful in how they play out their cards.

At the start of the game, players will draft cards to build the decks that they will play with for the duration of the game.

—description from the publisher

Name: Goto Hell! Saipan, June 17 1944
Description:
In the pre-dawn darkness, Japan's Col. Goto launches a massive (by Japanese standards) armored attack against the US Marines on Saipan. All but one of his 44 tanks were wrecks by morning. Marines joked that Japan's T-97 tanks were nothing more than "kitchen sinks."

Part of Against the Odds Magazine's Pocket Battle Games series, this postcard-sized game covers the armored attack led by Col. Goto against US Marines on Saipan, June 17, 1944.

ATO Pocket Battle #26.

Name: Radiation Dust: Fall of the Soviet Union
Description:
Radiation Dust: Fall of the Soviet Union takes place in the 1970s in a parallel universe.  U.S.-led NATO countries launched a full-scale nuclear attack against the Soviet Union. This game is not pure fiction but instead based on a real-life battle plan from the US Department of Defense.
“Operation Dropshot” was devised in 1949, early in the Cold War, and was declassified in 1975. The plan was to drop 300 nuclear warheads and conduct strategic bombings on 100 cities and 200 targets in the Soviet Union to obliterate 85% of Soviet Union's war making capacity.

In this game, one player plays NATO and the other player plays the Warsaw Pact.

Name: Reactor
Description:
Reactor is an intense and competitive contest where each player must react to the alarms of the reactor core before their opponents. Played with Blinks, the world's first smart tabletop game system, Reactor is a high-speed battle that takes advantage of the distributed intelligence of Blinks pieces to create a constantly shifting gameboard and dynamic difficulty levels. Originally created at the Global Game Jam 2020, Reactor takes inspiration from competitive fighting games, and distills them down to an intense contest of reflexes and concentration.

SETUP:
Arrange your Blinks so that each player has a single-file pathway to the center Blink. If possible, each player’s path should be the same length. When you are finished setting up, long-press the center Blink to start the Reactor.

GAMEPLAY:
The center Reactor will continuously flash colors. If it flashes the same color twice in a row, players must press the Blink at the end of their path to “buzz in.” The order in which the players buzz in will be shown by the color of their path. The first player to buzz in becomes green, the last player becomes red, and all others become yellow. Any player that does not buzz in is considered “last” and also displays red.

After results are shown, any player with a red path must remove the last piece on their branch and set it on the table in reach of all other players. This piece is now “unstable,” and displays a spinning yellow pattern.

All players, in addition to watching the Reactor, must now keep their eyes on these unstable Blinks. When an unstable Blink erupts in a green display, any player can grab it off the table and add it to the end of their chain. If the Blink flashes red instead, it is permanently out of the game.

WIN CONDITION:
The game continues until all players but one have lost all the Blinks in their pathway.

PAY UP VARIANT
Reactor can also be played with a set of “Pay Up” rules. In this version, players who display red after buzzing in, either because they buzzed last or didn’t buzz at all, must give their end pieces to the green player instead of setting them aside. Because players “Pay Up” after each round, there are no unstable Blinks on the table.

This version of the game is more focused than the standard rules, and two evenly-matched players can battle it out for a very long time.

Name: Trailer Truckin'
Description:
Players start with one Semi and two trailers and $4000. Each player rolls the dice to determine where on the game board the player’s trailers are to be placed . Each location has a money amount which the player will earn by retrieving the trailer and bringing it to the terminal. The trailer is placed in a new random location every time it is brought back to the terminal. Players roll dice to move their Semis on the game board in turn. Players will encounter event spaces, penalties, and bonuses along the way. The first player to return to the terminal with both trailers and a predetermined amount of cash is the winner.

—user summary

Name: The World Undone: 1914 – Galitzia
Description:
The World Undone: 1914 Galicia covers the Galicia Campaign using The World Undone original system inspired by the late John Young’s take on the Marne by SPI.
 Units are divisions and smaller, turns are 1 day each, and a simple, low complexity rules engine makes it possible to 
simulate the entire campaign in less than 2-3 hours.

Players can combine the Galicia, East Prussia and Serbia Games together to simulate the entire Eastern Front in 1914.

—description from the publisher
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players
Series: The World Undone System (Conflict Simulations)

Name: The World Undone: 1914 – Serbia
Description:
The World Undone: 1914 Serbia covers the ill-fated Austo-Hungarian invasion into Serbia at the beginning of the war.

An overwhelmed but experienced and aggressive Serbian army  quickly made short work of 3 invading Austro-Hungarian armies during an operational campaign set in dense terrain with frequent counter-offensives.

The Austro-Hungarian forces were ultimately routed and would not return until they had the help of Germany and Bulgaria.

Units are Divisions and smaller. Turns are 1 day. Each hex is approximately 7.2 km.

Players can combine the Serbia, East Prussia and Galicia Games together to simulate the entire Eastern Front in 1914.

—description from the publisher
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players
Series: The World Undone System (Conflict Simulations)

Name: The World Undone: 1914 –  West Front
Description:
The World Undone: 1914 - West Front: a monster game covering the entire 1914 campaign on the Western Front from the outbreak on August 4th, to the end of the Race to the Sea on October 19th.

Scenarios are included for all of the other battles/phases of the campaign.

West Front, the largest of the World Undone games and rules  to combine this game with the others along with variants for the Schlieffen plan, along with ‘Schlieffen goes East’.

Each unit is represented at a division scale, so this is truly a massive game, but one that plays really quickly. 
The World Undone benefits from its super-simple turn structure and mechanics which allow players to not get overwhelmed by the size of the conflict and focus on maneuver.

SCALE: 

     1 day turns, 
     2-3000 men per SP, 
     7.2 Kilometer hexes (4.5 miles) 
     Grand Campaign is 76 turns


WEIGHT: 2/10
PLAYERS: 1-Many 
SOLITAIRE: 5/10

—description from the publisher
Families: Series: The World Undone System (Conflict Simulations)

Name: Secret Sinners
Description:
Secret Sinners is a turn-based strategic card game where each player must fight in a King of the Hill-esque setting to earn the only spot through the gates of heaven. Hide your past sins carefully and accuse others of being evil to send them straight down the fiery depths of hell!

Each player’s character card is randomly placed in a vertical line formation, between heaven and hell, to create the play area.

The goal: Be the first player to enter Heaven with the help of the only Heaven’s Bell card, by being the last player in the line when all others have fallen into Hell or by confessing all your sins.

Players take turns playing different Action cards. Use these cards to scheme diabolical strategies, affecting the character line in various ways. Betray, steal and “sin” your way to victory!

As the game progresses, players will accumulate Sin cards. Discuss amongst yourselves to flesh these players out! Hide your sins carefully, for any suspicious player might accuse you and mark you as an evil player. On the other hand, if you manage to go unnoticed and accumulate enough sin cards, you can confess all your sins and win the game!

There are multiple Hell’s Bell cards and one single Heaven’s Bell card that players will draw as the game progresses. These cards stay in play and are activated at the end of the player’s turn, either granting victory to the player closest to heaven or severely punishing the player in front of hell.

—description from the designer

Name: Buy Peace With None: Six Scenarios for Whuppin' Jonathon
Description:
Buy peace with none.

Six ready to go scenarios enabling you to refight some of the most iconic battles of the struggle.  
Each has a map, full orders of battle, special rules and explanations, and a brief historical summary.  
Designed for use with Whuppin’ Jonathon, Vandering Publication’s wargames rules for recreating land warfare in the War of 1812, but capable of being adapted for any ruleset.

The scenarios are:

     Queenston Heights - the first real battle of the war of 1812.  The British are hopelessly outnumbered but have a good defensive position against an overwhelming number of decidedly indifferent American militia.  It’s a race against time for the Americans to land enough troops to overwhelm the defenders before more British troops arrive.
     Frenchtown (from the British version of the rules Whuppin’ Jonathon).  An attack upon a defended position with very nearly equal numbers of troops.
     Stoney creek - a desperate surprise night attack by a small British force against a much larger American one.  The attackers have only a few turns to win before they are overwhelmed.
     Chippewa - one the largest set piece battles of the war.  It is the basis for two scenarios. The first is an epic struggle in occluded terrain between opposing light infantry forces.  The second is a full scale “knock-em” out massed musketry duel.
     Lundy’s Lane - the most even large scale battle of the war.  The British have the numbers and a good defensive position, the Americans are more concentrated and, overall, have better quality troops and equipment.


This is the AMERICAN version of this scenario book, featuring US spelling, priority, and letter format.  The UK version is A smell of Gunpowder.

—description from the publisher

Name: A Smell of Gunpowder: Six War of 1812 Scenarios for use with Whuppin' Jonathon
Description:
A smell of gunpowder

Six ready to go scenarios enabling you to refight some of the most iconic battles of the struggle.  
Each has a map, full orders of battle, special rules and explanations, and a brief historical summary.  
Designed for use with Whuppin’ Jonathon, Vandering Publication’s wargames rules for recreating land warfare in the War of 1812, but capable of being adapted for any ruleset.

The scenarios are:

     Queenston Heights - the first real battle of the war of 1812.  The British are hopelessly outnumbered but have a good defensive position against an overwhelming number of decidedly indifferent American militia.  It’s a race against time for the Americans to land enough troops to overwhelm the defenders before more British troops arrive.
     Stoney creek - a desperate surprise night attack by a small British force against a much larger American one.  The attackers have only a few turns to win before they are overwhelmed.
     Chippewa - one the largest set piece battles of the war.  It is the basis for two scenarios. The first is an epic struggle in occluded terrain between opposing light infantry forces.  The second is a full scale “knock-em” out massed musketry duel.
     Lundy’s Lane - the most even large scale battle of the war.  The British have the numbers and a good defensive position, the Americans are more concentrated and, overall, have better quality troops and equipment.
     Malcolm Mills (from the American version of the rules “Whuppin’ John Bull”).  A superior American force tries to rout a smaller British one in a good defensive position before reinforcements arrive.


This is the BRITISH version of this scenario book, featuring anglicised spelling, priority and A5 format.  
The US version is "Buy peace with none".

—description from the publisher

Name: Power Rangers: Heroes of the Grid – Rise of the Psycho Rangers
Description:
Created from the power of the Dark Specter, the Psycho Rangers have risen! Designed to be faster, stronger, and smarter than the Power Rangers, each Psycho Ranger was created with the sole purpose of annihilating their Power Ranger counterpart!

With the Astro Megaship as their new command center and a whole new set of Zords to summon, can veterans Andros, Carlos, T.J., Ashley, and Cassie band together to overcome the assault of the terrifying Psycho Rangers?

This expansion also introduces Mastermind Mode, which allows one player to take control of the forces of evil, pitting player against player in a battle of wits! -- Description from publisher
Families: Game: Power Rangers: Heroes of the Grid
Series: Power Rangers Heroes of the Grid Phase 2

Name: Power Rangers: Heroes of the Grid – Villain Pack #2: Machine Empire
Description:
The Royal House of Gadgetry has arrived to conquer Earth! With all of their mechanical might, the Machine King and his coterie prepare for battle. The Power Rangers' skills will be put to the test as they deal with the machinations of this catastrophic clockwork court.

Meet the Machine Empire! The devious Prince Gasket, the heir to the throne, is joined by the enchanting Princess Archerina, while the egotistical Louie Kaboom plots their downfall. Big Bad General Venjix leads the empire's forces, and King Mondo himself rules with an iron fist and his terrifying Sword of Damocles.

This expansion introduces the concept of paired monsters. Are you brave enough to face Prince Gasket and Princess Archerina together as a deadly double act?
Families: Game: Power Rangers: Heroes of the Grid
Series: Power Rangers Heroes of the Grid Phase 2

Name: Queen of the Seas
Description:
Queen of the Seas,Pre-Dreadnought Rules,An attempt at a set of naval wargame rules for the period from about 1890 to about 1920
a Ruleset with a less detailed approach than other overly detailed naval rules for the period.

     firing and 
     damage determination 


can all be done reasonably quickly, 
thus allowing large actions to be played in a reasonable amount of time, and with a minimum amount of bookkeeping.

Name: Ironclads: 1850-1890
Description:
An attempt at a set of wargame rules for the ironclad period 1850 to 1890.

A simple set of rules for larger actions in the Ironclad period.

     movement,
     firing, and
     damage determination can all be done reasonably quickly.


Thus allowing for larger actions to be played in a reasonable amount of time, and with a minimum amount of bookkeeping.

Name: El Palé: TelePizza
Description: El PalÃ© is a Spanish game very similar to Monopoly. The standard El Palé had a square board with 11 spaces on each side. The TelePizza promotional version (released as a marketing campaign for the large Spanish pizza chain, co-sponsored by Coca-Cola) had a smaller, rectangular board, with 9 spaces on the longer sides and 7 spaces on the shorter sides. Instead of the standard version's streets of Madrid, the properties in this version are city names from throughout Spain, as well as TelePizza factory locations and methods of delivery transportation. The currency was redesigned to feature a pizza chef silhouette in the middle, and says it is from "Banco Telepizza". The Suerte (Luck) cards have the TelePizza logo on the back, and the Sorpresa (Surprise) cards have the Coca-Cola logo on the back.

Name: Glorantha: The Gods War – Dragons
Description:
The Red, Black, and Brown dragons add a balancing aspect to your Gods War game. The Black Dragon draining enemies of power, the Red Dragon drains enemies of victory points and the Brown Dragon generating runes for it’s controller. Every turn the player with the lowest power during the council phase will end up controlling one of these monstrosities, sowing havoc across the board.

Contents:
Huge Miniatures
3 Dragon Loyalty cards
3 Dragon Gifts

Name: Glorantha: The Gods War – Chaos Monsters
Description:
These monsters truly add an element of chaos to the battlefield and appear when the chaos rift opens. The Mother of Monsters enacts the ability for all players to create spawnlings and sent them into battle. All Chaos monsters can be activated by all players and tend to unbalance the game as the players with the most power get the most use form them.

Contents: 
3 Huge Miniatures 
3 Chaos Monster Loyalty cards 
3 Chaos Monster Gift Cards

Name: Артефактум (Artefactum)
Description:
Artefactum – strategic card game in the mystical Sigillum universe, in which players are pitted against each other until only one remains.

     Hire and level up your heroes to expand and adapt your army to everchanging situation.
     Summon creatures on the battlefield to utilize their attacks and unique abilities.
     Combine heroes. Characters of same faction or class grant access to powerful artifacts that can tip the battle in your favour.
     Utilize efficient formations. Each unit has predetermined combat behavior - similar to auto battler systems.

Name: Veggie Loto
Description: Oh my! The fruits and vegetables have escaped from the basket! To recover them, you must roll the best dice combinations to win counters. The first player to place all their counters on their lotto card is declared the winner. The ideal game to boost concentration and develop strategic thinking.

Name: Star Battle 2275 AD
Description:
Star Battle 2275 AD is a free PNP solitaire hex-based space combat simulator wargame for 1 player. Use your fleet of fighters to attack and destroy the enemy fleet. But watch out for fighters, cruisers, battle stations and asteroids. Can also be played by 2 players, with one player replacing the AI.

You will need:
This rule set
2 pages of Command Cards and counters (14 cards, 17 counters)
4 hex map pages (or you can use any printed one-inch hex map)
1 6d
colored beads or cubes as markers

In 2-player play, both fleets should be chosen so that their total number of Shield points, added together, is roughly equal. For solo play, give the AI side a 25-50% advantage. Solitaire players can play either fleet, and use the AI system to determine the opponent’s movements.

For small fleets with no more than 2 or 3 ships per side, two Hex Map boards should provide sufficient space. Larger fleets may require all four Hex Map boards for sufficient room.

Each turn, the Players move the ships in their fleet. In solo play, an AI dice table determines the opponent's moves. Ships maneuver to get within firing range of their opponent's ships. Combat is resolved by dice throw.

The difficulty level of Star Battle 2275 AD can be adjusted by varying the number and type of ships in each fleet. The game can also be made more difficult by adding navigational hazards such as Asteroids, which block line of sight and prevent travel within the hexes they cover.

Players win by destroying the opponent fleet.

—description from the designer

Name: Good Cop Bad Cop: Promoted
Description:
Promoted is an expansion to Good Cop Bad Cop in which you play a series of games and earn medals for your heroism during the game. Those medals are used to get promotions in the next game, which provide a unique action you can take that no one else can.

Medals also have victory points on them, so at the end of the series, you count up your victory points to see whether you win!

—description from the publisher

Name: Steampunk Rules!
Description:
Steampunk Rules!
A set of rules for fantastical skirmish games in the late Victorian era, each player usually has a force of 5-10 28mm figures. 
Ideal for multi-player games with an umpire to create a scenario to play.

Comes with some example forces to use or as a guide to creating your own and also a multi-player scenario.

—description from the publisher

Name: Stars and Steel
Description:
Stars and Steel is compact, modular and highly playable mass spaceship wargame!

What make the Stars and Steel unique?


     First – it’s really mass scale wargame in the space opera style! Players lead the entire fleets and the basic unit is the squadron of huge warships. The typical mid size fleet can consists of a few dozens destroyers, cruisers and battleships and big fleets can consist of more than a hundred spaceships!
     The battles can be resolved quickly without bogging into the details, as from game point of view the squadron is considered as whole.
     Fast, but flexible fleet and squadron composition, which favours experiments, variety and new combinations. In short: buy commanders, choose one of a few possible pre-set composition for them and fill it with ships from different classes.
     Squadron commanders skills has crucial role! They are not determined only by the rank (which determines squadron size), but also commanders leading style.
     Orders, which are divided into basic (performed automatically) and advanced (commander’s test is required) add extra risk management aspect.
     Formation system – the squadron can be in close or loose formation, both have bonuses and penalties.
     Disorganisation – the squadrons which are under fire start to lose coherency and the breaking enemy formations are very important aspect of the game.
     Modules – the game is designed as modular from the beginning. Modules add extra rules, scenarios, ships and other game aspects.
     Miniatures, in Nanofleet scale (1:10000), perfect for 3D printing. 


—description from the publisher

Name: Stars and Steel: Fate and Glory
Description:
Fate and Glory

Card based Stars and Steel module adding the random in-game events.

Includes one page of rules and 48 event cards for double-side printing.

Name: Lone Panzer
Description:
It is July of 1943; Germany's 4th Panzer army just suffered mayor defeat at Prokhorovka. One panzer IV tank got caught behind enemy lines, inside are 5 crew members suffering from battle stress, scared and alone, far from friendly units. They will have to traverse 40 km through enemy territory and try to reach their HQ.

Lone Panzer is a solitary game played around 30-60 minutes. Player will take control of all 5 crew members and try to move his tank from one side of the map to another, encountering enemy units and testing skills of his crew against other difficulties.

—description from the designer

Name: Turisteando
Description:
Travel around South America, a part of the world full of places of international fame as well as  fascinating hidden gems that every tourist should know. Compete to be the best tourism reviewer ever!

The game come with enough components to play different modes, which give you a unique way to play the game, each distinct from the other.

To travel, you just have to use the right ticket: bus for the roads, ship for the rivers or the sea, and airplane between airports. You can use it to travel once per turn, but if you pay attention, the tickets also have a destination and if you start or finish your travel in those places, then you can travel one more time!

To win, you must achieve the best reputation among the players. To increase it, you have to meet certain objectives like getting postcards, completing a route, going to trending or unexplored places, and much more according to the mode you're playing in.

—description from the designer

Name: Bide
Description:
Bide is a combinatorial, abstract strategy game for 2-6 players played on a hexagonal or square board which is initially empty (hex-hex base 5 is recommended). Bide was designed by Alek Erickson in May 2020.

Players can skip turns to get extra turns later: 
Players take turns placing stones of their color in the hexagonal cells. At the beginning of your turn, you are given a new stone. You can either play it, or "bide" (meaning wait). If you bide, set the stone aside and your turn ends immediately. The stone remains in your hand. If you play the new stone while having at least one stone still in hand, you may "release" (meaning play every stone in your hand in succession). If a player releases, all opponents must immediately release next turn, including their stone for that turn.

Stones create shock waves:
When a stone is placed, it creates a "shock wave": all adjacent stones move one space in the direction radially outward from the placement. If there are multiple connected stones adjacent to the placed stone, positioned directly in the line of the shock wave, they all move one space. If this movement causes a stone to bump into another stone directly in the line of the shock wave, that stone also gets pushed one space (becoming adjacent along a different grid line does not count). However, stones cannot be pushed past the edges of the board, and lines that are full between the edges and placed stone do not move.

Players get points for owning the center:
When the board is full, players score the position. Each stone is worth points equal to its distance from the nearest edge (starting at zero). Groups consist of connected, adjacent stones of a single color. Groups are worth the sum of their stones. The player with the highest scoring group wins. If tied, remove the outer-most ring of pieces and re-score, repeating this process until there is a winner.

—description from the designer

Name: Hostile Environment: Walk – Mech Skirmish Rules
Description:
In 2042, the world has entered a state of Total Anarchy.

P68P, an airborne poisonous pollen has wiped out 20% of the Earth’s population with no answer in sight. The United States has broken apart into a civil war, while a World War wages on in the East. Walks, giant war machines clash across the lands burying their enemies in their dust.

Hostile Environment: Walk is a fast-playing tactical miniatures wargame for 1-4 players.

It is played on hex maps with 1/285th scale miniatures. It uses a chit-pull system to keep opponents on their toes. Each round is broken into four action phases for each squad. Players may activate any single unit, or they may roll dice in an attempt to activate extra units.

Once activated, a unit uses Action Points to flank its enemies and unleash Hell. The action is fast and vicious.

Chain guns, rail guns, lasers, missiles, rockets, toxic smoke, and fire rip through armor leaving death in its wake.

Each unit comes with a card to track its ammo, heat, special abilities, and hit points. With an array of over 10 different weapon systems and hardpoints, players can create the Walk of their dreams.

Players form their crews with Walks, tanks, artillery, and other post-modern war machines, then battle over different scenarios for victory.

—description from the publisher

Name: Skirmish Elite: Normandy '44 – Falaise Firestorm
Description:
Skirmish Elite: Normandy ’44- Falaise is a complete book for recreating skirmish-level battles and campaigns centered on the fierce fighting to close the Falaise Gap in August 1944.

The book features the Allied 90th U.S. Infantry, 4th Canadian Armoured and 1st Polish Armoured Divisions trying to prevent the escape of the German 2nd Panzer and 3rd Parachute Divisions. 
Simultaneously, the 2nd SS Panzer Division is attacking into the pocket to aid the escape. 
The book includes ten scenarios that can be played alone or together in three linked campaigns.

Maximum Replayability: the Skirmish Elite system features a realistic variable order of battle for each scenario, guaranteeing countless unique scenario and campaign replays.

Generic Order of Battle: this book also includes a unique generic order of battle listing that can be translated to any skirmish rule system.

Historical Research: this book contains a unit-by-unit day-by-day account of the chaotic fighting.

—description from the publisher

Name: Skirmish Elite: Normandy '44 – Operation Overlord
Description:
Skirmish Elite: Operation Overlord is a complete book for recreating the battles and campaigns of American Airborne soldiers of the 505th PIR (82nd Airborne Division) on June 6-7 1944 as part of the invasion of France.
 This book includes ten scenarios – four from the battles for Neuville-au-Plain, and six from the battles for St. Mere-Eglise.
Maximum Replayability:  The Skirmish Elite system features a realistic variable order of battle for each scenario, guaranteeing countless unique scenario and campaign replays.
Generic Order of Battle:  This book also includes a unique generic order of battle listing that can be translated to any skirmish rule system.
Historical Research:  This book contains background information and maps of the battle area.

Includes: 

     10 Scenarios,
     3 Campaigns


—description from the publisher

Name: Skirmish Elite: Aussies at Bardia
Description:
SKIRMISH ELITE: Aussies at Bardia 1941

This is a complete book for recreating skirmish-level battles and campaigns centered on the 6th Australian Division’s struggle in North Africa to capture the fortress of Bardia from four Italian divisions in January of 1941. 
The book includes eight scenarios that can be played alone or together in one of two campaigns.

Generic Order of Battle: this book also includes a unique generic order of battle listing that can be translated to almost any skirmish rule system.

Historical Research: this book includes several introduction sections that contain background information and two maps on the campaign for Bardia.

Includes: 

     8 Scenarios,
     2 Campaigns


—description from the publisher

Name: Skirmish Elite: Combat Jump – Sicily
Description:
Skirmish Elite: Combat Jump - Sicily

WW2: The 82nd Airborne vs the Herman Goring Division
(8) scenarios and (2) campaigns.

A complete book for recreating skirmish-level battles and campaigns centered on the 82nd Airborne Division’s capture of the strategic road junction “Objective Y” on the first day of the invasion of Sicily in 1943

—description from the publisher

Name: Candy Monsters
Description:
The candy has been stolen and everything points towards those thieving Candy monsters. Now it’s up to you to get the candy back but beware. You’re not the only one on the hunt.

In Candy monsters 2-4 players are rolling dice and comparing those dice to the monstercards in the middle of the board. Beating those monsters gives the players candy which is also points in the game. Some monsters drop keys which can be used for opening chests. But beware, when moving your pawn at the candy/point track sometimes reveals a trap stopping your movement
The first to get to the Candy monsters cave (30 points) wins immediately.

- Description from the designer

Name: Skirmish Ragers: Medieval Mayhem – Medieval  Funfair
Description:
Medieval Mayhem is the first supplement to Skirmish RAGERS, and has been completed in collaboration with Studio Miniatures.

Medieval Mayhem adds a different dimension to the core rules. The tourists in the Medieval Mayhem Medieval Funfair were expecting entertainment, valiant knights, humble peasants and damsels in distress. Instead, they got the outbreak of a zombie apocalypse. While not the best place to find ones self when the zombie horde surface it was far from the worst. The knights may be fake, but at least their weapons are sharp(ish), and of course the armour offers some form of protection!

Do you have what it takes to gain a position at the round table, or even just a seat at Ye Olde Pub...

—description from the publisher

Name: Skirmish Elite: Struggle for Maleme – The Invasion of Crete, Vol.1
Description:
Skirmish Elite: Struggle for Maleme - The Invasion of Crete is a complete book for recreating skirmish-level battles and campaigns centered on the German 7th Fliegerdivision Fallschirmjagers and the 5th New Zealand Brigade around the Allied airfield at Maleme on Crete, May 1941.

The book includes eight scenarios that can be played alone or together in one of three campaigns. The book is the first of two Skirmish Elite books that will focus on Crete.

Maximum Replayability: the Skirmish Elite system features a realistic variable order of battle for each scenario, guaranteeing countless unique scenario and campaign replays.

Historical Research: this book includes several introduction sections that contain background information and history on the German invasion of Crete. This book also features a bibliography of sources.

Includes: 

     8 Scenarios,
     3 Campaigns.

Name: FunkiFruit
Description:
In this fast-paced fruit card game - FunkiFruit. You are searching a juicy crate.

Collect fruits, throw rotten tomatoes at your 'friends' and use actions to amass the most impressive platter. Beware, the starving insects bite: think Biker Slugs and Viking Ants!

There is something here for everyone, with classic 'take that' elements and good luck that rewards strategic planning. It's time to sharpen your memory and bring your inner 'Angry Farmer' to the table.

FunkiFruit can be enjoyed by players of all ages. You can customise your experience with our included fruit menu, to keep your game ripe and fresh!

—description from the designer

Name: Skirmish Elite: Crete – Stalemate in the East
Description:
Skirmish Elite: Crete - Stalemate in the East is a complete book for recreating skirmish-level battles and campaigns centered on the Central and Eastern Assault Group battles and campaigns in the German parachute assault on Crete in 1941. 
The book includes eight scenarios that can be played alone or together in one of two campaigns. This book is compatible with the previous Skirmish Elite book, Struggle for Maleme – The Invasion of Crete, Vol. 1.

Maximum Replayability: the Skirmish Elite system features a realistic variable order of battle for each scenario, guaranteeing countless unique scenario and campaign replays.

     8 Scenarios,

—description from the publisher

Name: Pylos
Description:
Abstract strategy game played on a board divided into two "hemispheres" of 10 spaces each, plus an "equator" of nine spaces. Each player receives 10 pieces of five different sizes which are placed in their hemisphere.

The game consists of five "battles", in each of which each player plays up to two pieces onto the equator. Only some pieces may be legally played depending on which spaces on the equator have been occupied, and the winner of the battle is determined by the sizes of the pieces.

The winner is the player who has won the majority of the pieces in battles, after all five battles are complete.

—user summary

Name: Arlequin
Description:
Arlequin is a chess variant played on an 8x8 board colored in a pattern of red, yellow and blue squares. Pieces (except for the king) are translucent tiles of yellow and blue plastic, with different colored markings on them showing parts of chess pieces. When the piece moves to a different colored square, different markings blend into the background color and a different piece type becomes visible.

The object, as in chess, is to checkmate the opposing king.

—user summary

Name: Skirmish Elite: The Russo-Polish War 1919 – Battle of the Borderlands
Description:
Skirmish Elite: Russo-Polish War 1919 - Battle of the Borderlands is a complete book for recreating skirmish-level battles and campaigns centered on the opening months of fighting in the Borderlands between Poland and Soviet Russia in 1919.

The book includes eight scenarios that can be played alone or together in one of three campaigns.

—description from the publisher

Name: SkirmishCampaigns: Belgium '40 – Hunters of the Ardennes
Description:
SkirmishCampaigns: Belgium '40-Hunters of the Ardennes is a complete book for recreating skirmish-level battles and campaigns centered on the opening day of fighting in Belgium in May 1940.

The book includes twelve scenarios that can be played alone or together in one of four campaigns. Maximum Replayability: the Skirmish Elite system features a realistic variable order of battle for each scenario, guaranteeing countless unique scenario and campaign replays.

Generic Order of Battle: this book also includes a unique generic order of battle listing that can be translated to almost any skirmish rule system.
